verses.text: Now there was a man of the Pharisees named Nicodemus, a ruler of the Jews.
verses.comment: Nicodemus later appears as one who defends Jesus (John 7:50) and brings spices for His burial (John 19:39). His role shows both initial intrigue and later devotion.

verses.text: He came to Jesus at night and said to Him, 'Rabbi, we know that You are a teacher who has come from God, for no one can do these signs You do unless God is with him.'
verses.comment: Coming by night may symbolize seeking truth in spiritual darkness. Nicodemus recognizes the divine origin of Jesus' works. 'Signs' refers to miracles that validate Jesus’ authority.

verses.text: Jesus answered him, 'Truly, truly, I say to you, unless one is born again, he cannot see the kingdom of God.'
verses.comment: 'Born again' can also mean 'born from above' (Greek: anothen). Jesus teaches spiritual rebirth as essential for entering God's kingdom—a reference to spiritual regeneration, later fulfilled in Christian initiation.

verses.text: Nicodemus said to Him, 'How can a man be born when he is old? Can he enter a second time into his mother's womb and be born?'
verses.comment: Nicodemus misunderstands Jesus’ spiritual teaching, thinking only in physical terms. This dialog underlines the necessity of spiritual discernment given by the Spirit.

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'Truly, truly, I say to you, unless one is born of water and the Spirit, he cannot enter the kingdom of God.'
verses.comment: 'Water and the Spirit' echoes Ezekiel 36:25–27: purification and indwelling Spirit. In Christian tradition, this points to sacramental rebirth, connected to water baptism and the Holy Spirit’s work.

verses.text: That which is born of the flesh is flesh, and that which is born of the Spirit is spirit.
verses.comment: Jesus contrasts natural birth (“flesh”) and spiritual birth (“Spirit”). Only the Spirit can bring about the new life needed to enter God’s kingdom.

verses.text: Do not marvel that I said to you, 'You must be born again.'
verses.comment: Jesus insists this new birth is necessary for all, not just extraordinary individuals. The phrase 'must' emphasizes its universal requirement.

verses.text: The wind blows where it wills, and you hear its sound, but you do not know where it comes from or where it goes. So it is with everyone who is born of the Spirit.'
verses.comment: The Greek word for 'wind' and 'Spirit' is the same (pneuma). The Spirit’s activity is mysterious yet undeniable, like the wind—pointing to the invisible, sovereign action of God in new birth.

verses.text: Nicodemus said to Him, 'How can these things be?'
verses.comment: Nicodemus still struggles to grasp spiritual realities, reflecting the need for faith and openness to God’s mystery.

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'Are you the teacher of Israel and yet you do not understand these things?'
verses.comment: Jesus expects spiritual leaders to recognize God’s promises from the Old Testament about inner renewal (see Ezekiel 36; Jeremiah 31).

verses.text: Truly, truly, I say to you, we speak of what we know and testify to what we have seen, but you do not accept our testimony.
verses.comment: Jesus speaks with the authority of heavenly knowledge, yet not all receive His testimony, pointing toward faith’s necessity and openness to God’s revelation.

verses.text: If I have told you earthly things and you do not believe, how will you believe if I tell you heavenly things?
verses.comment: Earthly (visible) realities prepare us for understanding deeper, spiritual truths. Faithful acceptance of simpler truths is prerequisite for grasping the mysteries of faith.

verses.text: No one has ascended into heaven except He who descended from heaven, the Son of Man.
verses.comment: Jesus presents Himself as the unique revealer from heaven, emphasizing His divine pre-existence and authority (Daniel 7:13).

verses.text: And just as Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, so must the Son of Man be lifted up,
verses.comment: The brazen serpent prefigures Jesus’ crucifixion. Looking upon the lifted Son brings eternal life, paralleling salvation for those who looked upon the serpent (Numbers 21).

verses.text: that whoever believes in Him may have eternal life.
verses.comment: Faith in Jesus, the Son of Man, brings divine life—eternal participation in God himself.

verses.text: For God so loved the world that He gave His only Son, that whoever believes in Him should not perish but have eternal life.
verses.comment: This central verse expresses the depth of God’s self-giving love. 'Only Son' (Greek: monogenes) indicates Jesus' unique relationship with the Father. Eternal life is union and communion with God.

verses.text: For God did not send His Son into the world to condemn the world, but in order that the world might be saved through Him.
verses.comment: The mission of Jesus is to bring salvation, not immediate condemnation, offering grace for all people.

verses.text: Whoever believes in Him is not condemned, but whoever does not believe is condemned already, because he has not believed in the name of the only Son of God.
verses.comment: Salvation is closely tied to faith in Jesus, God's unique Son. Refusal is self-condemnation, since it rejects the life and grace God offers.

verses.text: And this is the judgment: the light has come into the world, and people loved the darkness rather than the light, because their deeds were evil.
verses.comment: Jesus is the true Light. Choosing darkness over light is a moral decision, exposing the need for repentance and moral transformation.

verses.text: For everyone who does evil hates the light and does not come to the light, lest his deeds should be exposed.
verses.comment: Sin leads to avoidance of the divine Presence. The light uncovers, heals, and purifies, an ongoing dynamic in the spiritual life.

verses.text: But whoever does what is true comes to the light, so that it may be clearly seen that his deeds have been carried out in God.
verses.comment: Drawing near to God’s light reveals authentic good works, done by grace. Spiritual transformation enables true righteousness.

verses.text: After this, Jesus and His disciples went into the region of Judea, and there He remained with them and was baptizing.
verses.comment: Although John 4:2 clarifies Jesus did not baptize personally, this shows baptism was part of the early community under His direction—signifying the importance of sacraments administered in His name.

verses.text: John also was baptizing at Aenon near Salim, because water was plentiful there, and people were coming and being baptized.
verses.comment: John’s ongoing ministry points to the transition between the old covenant and the new, preparing hearts for Christ.

verses.text: For John had not yet been put in prison.
verses.comment: This is a chronological note, connecting the narrative to John’s later imprisonment, clarifying the timing of the events.

verses.text: Now a discussion arose between some of John’s disciples and a Jew over purification.
verses.comment: This likely refers to Jewish ritual washings. John’s baptism and Jesus’ bring new meaning to purification—pointing beyond ritual to inner cleansing.

verses.text: And they came to John and said to him, 'Rabbi, He who was with you across the Jordan, to whom you bore witness—look, He is baptizing, and all are going to Him.'
verses.comment: John’s followers note Jesus’ growing popularity. There is a shift from the preparatory ministry of John to the fullness in Christ.

verses.text: John answered, 'A person cannot receive even one thing unless it is given him from heaven.'
verses.comment: True ministry and spiritual gifts are received from God, not earned.

verses.text: You yourselves bear me witness that I said, 'I am not the Christ, but I have been sent before Him.'
verses.comment: John reaffirms his role as the forerunner, not the Messiah. Humility and faithful witness are hallmarks of authentic servants.

verses.text: The one who has the bride is the bridegroom. The friend of the bridegroom, who stands and hears him, greatly rejoices at the bridegroom’s voice. Therefore this joy of mine is now complete.
verses.comment: Jesus is the Bridegroom (cf. Isa. 62:5), fulfilling Old Testament imagery. John is the friend who rejoices in the union of Christ with His people—symbolic of intimate relationship.

verses.text: He must increase, but I must decrease.
verses.comment: John recognizes that his mission points forward to Jesus, who holds preeminence. This models humility and the right ordering of spiritual authority.

verses.text: He who comes from above is above all. He who is from the earth belongs to the earth and speaks in an earthly way. He who comes from heaven is above all.
verses.comment: Jesus’ heavenly origin distinguishes Him from all others, affirming His divinity and supreme authority.

verses.text: He bears witness to what He has seen and heard, yet no one receives His testimony.
verses.comment: Christ reveals firsthand knowledge of God. The world’s resistance to the message contrasts with those who accept it by faith.

verses.text: Whoever receives His testimony sets his seal to this, that God is true.
verses.comment: Accepting Jesus is affirming God’s truthfulness—a call to personal assent and faith.

verses.text: For He whom God has sent utters the words of God, for He gives the Spirit without measure.
verses.comment: Jesus speaks with full divine authority and imparts the fullness of the Spirit, a sign of the new covenant’s abundance.

verses.text: The Father loves the Son and has given all things into His hand.
verses.comment: The unique and eternal love between Father and Son, all authority being entrusted to Christ shows His divine status.

verses.text: Whoever believes in the Son has eternal life; whoever does not obey the Son shall not see life, but the wrath of God remains on him.
verses.comment: Faith and obedience are joined—eternal life comes through union with the Son. This points to salvation being lived out not only in belief but in faithful following and adherence to Jesus.
